step1.heading: Family Relationship & Category
step1.relationshipLabel: What is the relationship to the beneficiary?
step1.notEligibleDesc: A Lawful Permanent Resident cannot petition for this relationship category.
step1.categoryTooltip: The petition category is auto-detected based on the petitioner's status, relationship, beneficiary's age, and marital status.

step2.heading: Petitioner Information
step2.tooltip: The petitioner (sponsor) must demonstrate they can legally and financially support the petition.
step2.citizenshipMethodLabel: How did the petitioner obtain status?
step2.priorPetitionsLabel: Has the petitioner filed immigration petitions before?

step3.heading: Beneficiary Information
step3.tooltip: Information about the person who will receive the immigration benefit.
step3.locationLabel: Where is the beneficiary currently located?
step3.insideUSDesc: Currently present in the United States
step3.priorEntriesLabel: Has the beneficiary ever entered the U.S. before?
step3.lastEntryTypeLabel: Type of most recent entry to the U.S.

step4.heading: Processing Path Eligibility
step4.tooltip: Determines whether the beneficiary can adjust status inside the U.S. or must process at a consulate abroad.
step4.outsideNote: Since the beneficiary is outside the U.S., the case will proceed through Consular Processing.
step4.enteredLegallyLabel: Did the beneficiary enter the U.S. with a valid visa or lawful status?
step4.validStatusLabel: Does the beneficiary currently have valid immigration status?
step4.protection245iLabel: Does the beneficiary have 245(i) grandfathered protection?
step4.protection245iTooltip: Section 245(i) allows certain individuals to adjust status in the U.S. even if they entered without inspection or are out of status, provided a petition was filed before April 30, 2001.

step5.heading: Immigration History & Risks
step5.tooltip: These questions identify potential bars to immigration benefits that may require a waiver.
step5.unlawfulPresenceLabel: Has the beneficiary accumulated unlawful presence in the U.S.?
step5.deportationLabel: Has the beneficiary been deported or removed?
step5.falseDocsLabel: Has the beneficiary used false documents?

step6.heading: Criminal History
step6.tooltip: Criminal history can affect admissibility and may require a waiver or render the person ineligible.
step6.arrestsLabel: Has the beneficiary ever been arrested?
step6.offenseTypeLabel: Select all offense types that apply:

step7.heading: Petitioner Financial Capacity
step7.tooltip: The petitioner must demonstrate ability to financially support the beneficiary. This is required through the Affidavit of Support (Form I-864).
step7.coSponsorLabel: Is a joint sponsor (co-sponsor) available if needed?
step7.belowGuideline: Below 125% Poverty Guideline — Co-sponsor may be needed
step7.guidelineTooltip: For 2024, the 125% poverty guideline for a household of 2 is approximately $25,550, increasing by ~$6,950 per additional person.

step8.heading: Marriage Information
step8.tooltip: Additional details for spousal petitions to evaluate the marriage and assess fraud risk.
step8.priorMarriagesLabel: Have either spouse had prior marriages?
step8.evidenceLabel: Types of evidence of genuine relationship (check all that apply):
step8.marriageFraudWarning: Elevated Marriage Fraud Risk Indicators Detected
step8.recentMarriageNote: Marriage less than 2 years — conditional residence will apply (CR-1).

step9.heading: Petition Screening Results
step9.disclaimer: LEGAL DISCLAIMER: This screening is informational only and does not constitute legal advice. Final eligibility must be determined by a licensed immigration attorney.
step9.priorityReviewDesc: Complex factors detected that require specialized legal analysis.

alerts.saved: Petition screening results saved to client profile. (Data logged to console for validation)
